awd_titl_txt: The neural mechanisms of predictive coding during language comprehension
awd_abstract_narration:
During skilled reading, people recognize words from written character strings and combine words into a larger message-level interpretation. Reading is a pervasive part of modern human life, and impaired reading is highly detrimental to scholastic and professional success. Despite its importance, the neural processes that enable skilled readers to comprehend multi-word combinations remain poorly understood. In this research, Dr. Albert Kim and Dr. Phillip Gilley of the University of Colorado Boulder will use cutting edge neurophysiological methods to understand how the brain generates and uses predictions about the upcoming words within a text during reading, guided by prior linguistic context. Predictions are thought to support the fast pace of normal reading, which is typically 3-5 words per second, by allowing the brain to prepare in advance for anticipated text before it arrives in the retinal input. Predictions are also thought to be crucial to the common ability to perceive words accurately in the face of impoverished inputs, such as conditions of poor lighting, print quality, or visual acuity. The research in this project is expected to produce knowledge that guides the identification of reading disorders and distinctions between different sorts of disorders, which can in turn guide clinical and pedagogical approaches to reading disorders.

The project will use scalp-recorded encephalography (EEG) to observe neural oscillatory activity -- reflecting the dynamic coupling and uncoupling of neural networks -- while healthy young adults read sentences. The sentences that participants read will be manipulated so that some sentence contexts render a specific word likely to occur, according to computational language models.  Under these conditions, brain activity that occurs before and after the appearance of a word in the linguistic input will be examined for evidence of predictions. The project will investigate the role of neural oscillations in conveying predictions about upcoming words from high level brain regions to low level visual cortical areas and also in assessing the match between predictions and the bottom-up sensory input. The researchers will also study the types of linguistic contexts and processing demands that engage such predictive activity. Results of this research are expected to contribute significantly to cognitive neuroscience by combining three critical areas of research that have typically been studied separately: language processing, prediction in cognition, and neural oscillations. The project will develop new analytic methods for characterizing neural oscillations in EEG data, which will be developed into a toolbox to be shared with other researchers. The project will also produce a rich database of brain activity during the reading of naturalistic stories, which will be shared with the scientific community as a resource for further research.

por.por_cntn:
In this research, Dr. Albert Kim and Dr. Phillip Gilley of the University of Colorado Boulder used electrophysiological recordings from the scalp (EEG) to identify the neural mechanisms of predictive processing during human language comprehension. Predictions during language processing are thought to guide the recognition of words in the face of pervasive ambiguity (e.g., bear and pear sound similar) and environmental noise and to prepare the brain for the rapid pace of linguistic input, which arrives at 3-5 words per second in normal speech and reading. Predictions are also widely believed to contribute to learning, through a process that gradually adjusts knowledge to improve predictions whenever they are wrong (e.g., when we encounter a word that violates our predictions). Despite widespread and growing theoretical attention to predictive processing, empirical evidence indicating how predictions work has been scarce.

Our studies found clear evidence that language comprehenders predict both the meanings and the physical forms of individual words during sentence reading, based on prior linguistic context. Sentences were presented visually on a computer display, one word at a time at a rapid but comfortable pace. We recorded the brain activity elicited by each individual word. In order to measure the impact of predictions on language processing, we deliberately omitted some words from presentation, at moments when those words were potentially predictable (e.g., “The chef grabbed some flour, so she could bake a ------”;  likely next word is ‘cake’). At the moment when a word was expected to appear, only a vertical crosshair stimulus appeared. Brain responses to these empty crosshairs were proportional in amplitude to the lengths of the words that were predictable but failed to appear. This pattern of brain activity, which reflects the physical properties of a specific word that was not present in the sensory input, indicates that participants predicted the word. Our study provides clearest available evidence that predictions during language comprehension specify the physical form features of individual words.

We carefully examined the timing of these effects in order to learn about how the brain integrates information in the face of rapidly arriving inputs. We found that the predictions affected brain activity primarily in a time window about 150-300 ms after the moment when a critical word was expected to appear in the input. This timing suggests that the observed brain activity reflected an attempt to “reconstruct” the predicted word after it failed to appear in the input, based on predictions. We found no evidence that the predictable word’s representation was active prior to this time window, and we therefore conclude that the brain does not appear to “pre-activate” word representations, even though this possibility has been widely hypothesized. Instead, the predictions we observed seem to reflect preparation to rapidly integrate a word after it arrives in the input, but without actual specific perceptual representations.

Using mathematical modeling methods, we identified neuroanatomical sources of the prediction-related brain activity primarily within the left inferior temporal lobe and in the medial parietal lobe. The first of these brain regions is widely associated with visual perceptual processing, and its involvement in our effects corroborates our conclusions that that predictions act on low-level perceptual features, and not just on representations of a word’s abstract meaning. The second area is associated with the intersection of memory, attention, and vision, and its involvement is consistent with the crucial role of memory in the generation and testing of predictions and the updating of knowledge on the basis of prediction error.
